resources.string: Applying for a Class D License
Specific Groups and Special Health Concerns

1. Required hours of attendance at public school 
	 i. Every minor subject to laws pertaining to public schools is required to attend said schools/courses in the town of his employment for no less than 4 hours per week. 
	 ii. Attendance of minors who are required to attend continuation schools, and are temporarily out of work, are required to attend said school for no less than 20 hours per week. 
2. Compulsory education laws 
	 i. Children aged 7 and older are required to attend school, unless deemed mentally or physically unable to attend/ have immediate needs at home 
	 ii. In Massachusetts, individuals are required to attend school if they are under the age of 16 years. 
		 a. 14-16 year olds who have completed 6th grade and hold a permit for employment in domestic service or a farm, is regularly employed a minimum of 6 hours per day, and has written permission of superintendent to engage in non-wage earning employment at home are allowed to not attend school 
	 iii. Homeschool provisions approval is up to the superintendent and/or school committee - review curriculum, evaluation methods, textbooks, etc.
3. Federal Law 
	 i. States and school districts are required to provide all children in the U.S. with an equal access to a basic public education regardless of citizenship or immigration status. 
4. No refusing 
	 i. No school committee shall refuse a school-age child with a disability admission or continued attendance in a public school without prior written approval of the department and without complying with state and federal requirements for discipling students with disabilities

1. Required documents: proof of U.S. citizenship or lawful presence, Social Security number, and Massachusetts residency. 
	 a. Original documents, no photocopies or laminated documents 
	 b. One document cannot be used to prove more than one requirement 
	 c. Lawful presence: legally living in the U.S. according to federal immigration laws 
		 i. Non-U.S. citizens who are working, studying, or living temporarily in the U.S. might have temporary lawful presence that varies in length 
		 ii. For U.S. citizens: valid, unexpired U.S. passport or certified copy of U.S. birth certificate 
		 iii. For permanent residents: valid permanent resident card (green card) iv. For non-U.S. citizens: valid verifiable immigration documents and proof of grant of a legal stay in the U.S. for at least 12 months 
	 d. Social Security Number (SSN): must have a valid SSN (9 digit number) to apply for any learner\’s permit, driver\’s license, or ID card, bring one of the following: 
		 i. SSN card (not laminated) 
		 ii. W-2 Form - wage and tax statement 
		 iii. SSA 1099 Form - tax form for individuals who receive social security benefits 
		 iv. Pay stub with applicant's name and full SSN 
		 v. SSN denial notice with passport, visa and I-94 
	 e. Massachusetts residency documents: document showing current residential address(2 of the following documents for a Real ID, 1 for Standard driver's license) 
		 i. Massachusetts RMV-issued documents 
			 Ex) Current license, Massachusetts ID card, learner's permit, or RMV-issued correspondence 
		 ii. State/federal/municipal/city/town/country agency-issued documents 
			 Ex) 1st class government-issued mail, medicaid statement, current firearms card, or jury duty summons all dated within 60 days 
		 iii. Bills 
			 Ex) Utility bill (electric, telephone, water, cable, etc), credit card statement, medical statement, cell phone bill all dated within 60 days 
		 iv. Lease/Mortgage documents 
			 Ex) Current lease/mortgage or similar rental contract 
		 vi. Financial related document 
			 Ex) Bank statements, SSA statement, school-issued documents, insurance related documents 
2. Real ID vs Standard ID 
	 a. From Oct 2020, a Real ID can be used to fly within the United States or enter federal buildings 
3. Can start application online or start application at the RMV - https://atlas-myrmv.massdot.state.ma.us/myrmv/_/

1. Foreign-licensed drivers from another country that meet certain requirements* may operate a validly registered motor vehicle in Massachusetts for up to 1 year. After 1 year, any non-immigrant visa holder must obtain a Massachusetts Driver’s License in order to drive legally in the U.S. \n\t a. *Requirements: at least 16 years of age, in possession of a valid driver’s license when operating a motor vehicle, may operate the same type of vehicle in which licensed to operate in another country, license must not be suspended or revoked, if foreign license is not in English or doesn’t have an English translation, must have an International Driving Permit (IDP), a Translation into English of a Foreign License document, or an alternative translation documents that has a photo and English translation that closely matches information from an IDP.

1. Any licensed individual between the ages of 16 ½ and 18 is a Junior Operator 
2. Individuals are required to be at least 16 years of age before obtaining a learner’s permit 
3. Learner’s permits are obtained through the DMV/RMV 
4. Learner’s permit holders may drive if they have the learner’s permit while driving and when accompanied by a driver who is licensed, at least 21 years of age, has at least one year of driving experience, and is occupying the passenger’s seat (seat next to the driver) 
5. Students under the age of 18 applying for a license are required to have completed all of the requirements of drivers education: 30 hours of classroom education, 12 hours of behind-the-wheel driving, 6 hours of in-car observation, and parent attendance at a 2-hour parent class. 
6. After obtaining a Junior Operator License, the teen is prohibited from driving with any passengers under the age of 18, excluding any immediate family members, for the first 6 months unless accompanied by a licensed driver who is at least 21 years old. 
7. Anyone obtaining a Junior Operator License is prohibited from driving between 12:30 a.m. and 5 a.m. unless accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.

1. Individuals have freedom of speech, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly, freedom of the press, and the right to petition. 
2. Stopped by Police/Pulled over by police 
	 i. You have the right to remain silent. If you wish to exercise this right, say so out loud. 
	 ii. If arrested, you have the right to a government-appointed lawyer if unable to afford one of your own and the right to make a local phone call. 
	 iii. If police are at your door, they may not enter without a warrant signed by a judicial officer that lists your address or has your name on it. 
3. Voting in Massachusetts 
	 i. Individuals must be at least 18 years of age, a U.S. citizen, meet state’s residency requirements, and registered to vote by state’s voter registration deadline in order to vote. 
	 ii. Individuals must be a resident of the state - the amount of time you have been a resident does not matter 
	 iii. Registration deadline is 20 days before the election - voters can register online, mail, or in person at a registration office or the RMV. 
	 iv. Form of identification is required, acceptable forms: 
		 a. Valid driver’s license 
		 b. State issued identification card 
		 c. Current utility bill 
		 d. Bank statement 
		 e. Paystub 
		 f. Government-issued check 
		 g. Other government document that has voter’s name and address 
	 v. Automatic registration - MA automatically registers eligible individuals through the DMV, division of medical assistance, health insurance connector authority, and other agencies that collect reliable citizenship information 
	 vi. Online registration - Individuals can visit https://www.sec.state.ma.us/ovr/ to register online 
4. Marriage 
	 i. Same sex marriage is legal in all 50 states. 
	 ii. To obtain a marriage license, an individual must be at least 18 years of age. Parental consent is required for individuals under the age of 18. 
	 iii. Marrying a relative is illegal.

1. Federally Assisted Program 
	 i. Prohibits discrimination in federally assisted programs - no person in the U.S. can be excluded from, denied benefits of, or subject to discrimination under and program that receives federal assistance based on their race, color, or national origin (this includes limited proficiency in English) 
		 a. Examples of federally assisted programs: Child and Adult Care Food Program, Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, Alcohol, Drug Abuse, and Mental Health Services Block Grant 
2. Public Accommodation 
	 i. Prohibits making distinction, discrimination or restriction in admitting to a place of public accommodation based on race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, sexual orientation, disability, or ancestry 
3. State provided services 
	 i. All programs, activities and services provided by the state are required to be conducted without unlawful discrimination based on race, color, age, gender, ethnicity, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, religion, ancestry, national origin, disability, veteran status, or background 
4. Religious Freedom 
	 i. Employers are prohibited from discriminating on the basis of religion. 
	 ii. Religious discrimination in rental, sale, and financing of homes is prohibited. 
	 iii. School officials can not include religious activities into school events, impose their faith on students, require students to read religious texts without a secular reason for doing so, display religious symbols without a secular, academic reason, etc.

1. In Massachusetts, hand-held cell phone use by drivers is banned. If drivers want to talk on the phone while operating a motor vehicle they are required to use Bluetooth or another hands-free technology tool.

All people in Massachusetts, regardless of immigration status, have access to some sort of healthcare. For more information on the different forms of healthcare and what forms you are eligible for, see below:

There are a variety of different ways which can be done, but one of the easiest is the RHAP (Refugee Health Assessment Program). RHAP is a service provided by the Massachusetts Office for Refugees and Immigrants, and they work to provide services which are both linguistically and culturally appropriate to people who are newly arriving to the country. 
 In addition to primary assessment services, RHAP provides follow up check ups, immunizations, and referral to primary care services. 
 
 A second association which offers similar services is the Refugee Preventative Health Program (RHP) through the Office of Refugee Resettlement, provided by the federal government.

Individuals who have gained legal refugee status or anyone else eligible for Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) service (determine your eligibility here) but are not eligible for medicaid are entitled to 8 months of Refugee Medical Assistance. RMA provides similar benefits to medicaid, but to this specific population. Please note that: \n -This 8 month period starts on the date of arrival to the United States, not date of entering the program \n -After the 8 months have elapsed, individuals must determine their qualified immigrant status to see what healthcare they are eligible for. Learn more about qualified immigrant status here.

Some important information on healthcare in Massachusetts: 
-HIPAA laws mean that health professionals cannot give away personal information about (but not limited to) immigration, and so going to the doctor, the health clinic, or the hospital is safe for everyone, and so is applying for public health insurance though MassHealth, the Health Connector and Mass Safety Net. 
-Getting health insurance does not warrant a public charge, and thus does not inhibit your ability to apply/get citizenship, nor does it affect your immigrant status. 

 For a factsheet with all of this information and more click here. 

 Want more information about the availability of health insurance, specifically in Massachusetts? Visit Healthcare for All 
 Want to start applying for Healthcare? Start with the Mass Health Connector Portal.

There are a variety of services provided by the state of Massachusetts for groups which may have specialized medical needs, both physical and mental. These groups include: 
-Women, particularly mothers to young children and infants 
-Victims of domestic violence 
-Victims of Trafficking 
-Victims of assault and/or abuse. 

 Information about all of these specialized services can be found at the bottom of this webpage.

Public charge is the law that prevents people who are likely to become a government expense from becoming citizens of the United States. The expenses which fall under public charge are cash assistance for income maintenance (such as SSI and TANF) and institutionalization for long term care. If it is determined that an non-citizen either constitutes a public charge or is likely to do so, they will lose their eligibility to become a lawful citizen.

The MBTA (Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority) is the association which is responsible for a collection of public transportation services which are offered in the Massachusetts area. The services are broken down based on the type of transportation provided, the region which it is available for, fees, accessibility, etc. Select a button below for more information:
Transportation systems in the Greater Boston Area:

The subway, or occasionally simply referred to as the “T” is a group of underground trains which travel specifically within the greater Boston area. The T is composed of 4 major lines: Red, Orange, Green, and Blue, but all of these lines do connect to each other, allowing for travel across all parts of the area. For a general guide on using the subway, click here. For more specific information see below:
